journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Proportional hazards model for reliability analysis of solder joints under various drop-impact and vibration conditions

contrib-group.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Dong Chuan Road 800, Shanghai, 200240, People’s Republic of China. email: youmingyi@gmail.com

abstract.p: This paper is devoted to the use of a proportional hazards model (PHM) for reliability analysis of solder joints through two case studies: a drop-impact test and a vibration test. The lifetime data collected under various load conditions can be integrated in establishing a PHM for reliability analysis of solder joints. PHM has the capability of evaluating the influence of load conditions (e.g. drop height, power spectrum density in random vibration) on the life span of solder joints. Using this capability, this paper focuses on the implementation of PHM for estimating the reliability characteristics (MTTF and probability density function (p.d.f.) of failure) of solder joints whose load conditions are not contained in the training dataset of the PHM. In comparison with the naive use of lifetime data by simply ignoring the effect of load conditions, the two case studies verify the effectiveness of PHM in providing consistent reasonable estimation of the reliability characteristics of solder joints. The perspectives and the procedures of the use of PHM in this paper are generic and can be directly adopted for other systems/products.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Portable electronic products (PEPs) such as mobile phones are very popular nowadays. However, these PEPs are prone to be accidentally dropped or be in a vibration environment. The drop impact or vibration can not only lead to housing crack, but also to crack of solder joints which interconnect the integrated circuit components to the printed circuit board (PCB). Moreover, the lead-free trend of solder joints makes them less robust against drop impact and vibration [1, 2]. Consequently, the reliability characteristics (e.g. mean time to failure (MTTF), probability density function (p.d.f.) of failure time) of solder joints become major concerns for manufacturers of PEPs.

In the literature, there exist many lifetime prediction models for solder joints under drop impact or vibration. For the drop-impact environment, most researchers have converged on postulating fatigue as the micro-damage mechanism for the solder joints, and have proposed several damage and failure models [3–5]. On the other hand, vibration-induced stresses can also lead to fatigue failure of solder joints. A high cycle fatigue life model, represented by a S–N (stress-life) curve, is often used to assess the vibration fatigue failure of solder joints [6]. Most of the above models consider stress or strain as the dominant variable. These models are effective for predicting the life-expectancy (i.e. MTTF) for a bath of identical solder joints under the same load conditions. In these models, the calculation of stress or strain under certain drop height or vibration acceleration level usually requires the aid of the finite element method (FEM). However, FEM is sensitive to boundary conditions and the results would be misleading if the boundary conditions are not close to reality. More importantly, it is usuallyhard to obtain the characteristics of lifetime variability by these lifetime models (i.e. p.d.f. of failure time), which is also an important statistical index.

On the other hand, the reliability characteristics for a batch of identical solder joints can be estimated by conducting a conventional reliability test for several samples under a specified condition (e.g. same drop height in a drop-impact test, same power spectrum density (PSD) in a vibration test) [7]. Such method could evaluate the lifetime variability of solder joints, but needs relatively large sample size. Usually, the existence of various load conditions may make the necessary sample size prohibitively large. Consequently, it is beneficial to be able to estimate the reliability characteristics of the solder joints whose load conditions are not contained in the historical dataset (dataset collected in a reliability test). By this motivation, this paper is devoted to the implementation of a proportional hazards model (PHM) for estimating the reliability characteristics of solder joints through two case studies (one under drop-impact condition, and the other under vibration condition), with emphasis on its capability of explicitly accounting for the influence of load conditions on the life span of solder joints. PHM has been maturely used in the field of medicine since the pioneering work of Cox in 1972 [8]. However, the use of PHM in reliability engineering is limited, mostly aiming to establish an optimal condition-based maintenance model[9, 10]. Thus, this study demonstrates another perspective on the use of PHM in reliability engineering.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 provides a brief review of the typical structure of PHM. Section 3 details the experiment setup and data collection, and discusses the implementation results. Finally, section 4 concludes the paper.

sec.title: 2 PHM
sec.p: In this section, we first briefly review the typical structure of PHM in section 2.1, then discuss the establishment of a PHM based on the training/historical samples in section 2.2.

sec.title: 2.1 PHM
sec.p: Typically, PHM can be written as

where λ(t;Z) is the hazard function, λ0(t) is the baseline hazard function which can be either parametric or non-parametric, Z′=(z1,…,zm) is the vector of covariates, and β′=(β1,…,βm) is the vector of regression coefficient, and m is the number of covariates. It is worth mentioning that the influence of covariates (e.g. load conditions for solder joints) on system life span is explicitly accounted for in equation (1).

In practice, the Weibull distribution is widely used as the baseline function for PHM [11, 12] due to its capability of modelling failure time data with either decreasing or increasing hazard function. In this paper, the Weibull hazard function is also adopted as the baseline hazard function for the PHM, and thus we have
where γ>0 and η>0 are the shape and scale parameters for Weibull distribution.

sec.title: 2.2 Parameter estimation
sec.p: To establish a PHM, it is necessary to find the values of γ,η,β in equation(2). In practice, these parameters are typically estimated by the maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) method [7]. First of all, it is assumed that right-censoring is adopted in preparing the training samples to establish a PHM, which is the most widely used censoring mechanism in a reliability test. In order to estimate γ,η,β in equation (2), it is necessary to collect (1) the time intervals from system initialization to failure or censoring, (2) the associated covariates, and (3) the event indicator δ, where δ=1 if failure occurs and δ=0 if right-censoring is performed.
Given n historical/training samples, the likelihood function of the collected data is

where n is the number of training samples, tj is the failure/censoring moment of sample j, δj is the event indicator of sample j, λj(·) and Rj(·) denotes the hazard function and reliability function of sample j respectively. In terms of the hazard function, we have
Typically, the natural logarithm of equation (4) is much easier for further analysis and is derived as
Substituting the hazard function in (2) and (4) into (5) gives
Then, the MLE chooses the values γ^,η^,β^ that maximize equation (6). Consequently, γ^,η^,β^ are also called the maximum likelihood estimators.
After the maximum likelihood estimators are found, the hazard rate function given a group of covariates Zgiven could be obtained by substituting γ^,η^,β^ and Zgiven into equation (2)
The reliability function is then
and the p.d.f. is
By equation (9), the life expectancy (MTTF) for a batch of systems given the conditions Zgiven can be derived as

where Γ(·) is the Gamma function, and Γ(k)=∫0∞tk−1exp(−t)dt. Thus, the typical structure and the training process of PHM have been covered. In the next section, we will discuss the implementation of PHM through two case studies.

sec.title: 3 Case Studies
sec.p: This section is devoted to the implementation of PHM to two lifetime datasets of solder joints collected in (1) a drop-impact test, and (2) a vibration test. In correspondence with the outline of our motivation in section 1, the focus here is on the capability of PHM for estimating the reliability characteristics of solder joints whose load conditions are not contained in the training dataset of the PHM. In the following, section 3.1 focuses on the drop-impact test, section 3.2 focuses on the vibration test, and section 3.3 provides some further discussions.

sec.title: 3.1.1 Experimental setup and process
sec.p: Ball grid array (BGA) packages mounted on a PCB were used for drop-impact test for their wide use in PEPs. For each PCB (160 mm diameter, 1 mm thickness), eight BGA packages were mounted centro-symetrically as shown in Fig. 1. The size of each BGA is 11 mm×13 mm. There are 103 solder joints on each BGA with the detailed layout shown in Fig. 2. The diameter of each solder joints is 0.35 mm, and the space between the centres of two consecutive solder joints is 0.8mm. The material of solder joints is lead-free Sn96.5 Ag3.0 Cu0.5. The detailed design process of the test board has been demonstrated in [13].

Equipment and instruments involved in the drop test can be categorized into two groups: (1) the testing system, used to fix the PCB and conduct the drop-impact test, and (2) the monitoring system, used to detect the failures of the BGA solder joints. The solder joints of interest were linked in series in a daisy chain loop, and the crack/break of any solder joint would lead to an abrupt change of the voltage across these linked solder joints, which was detected by an oscilloscope. We have already provided a detailed description of the testing and measurement systems in [14].

With the testing board, the testing system, and the monitoring system, three groups of drop-impact tests were conducted, with the drop height of 0.34 m (group 1, four PCBs), 0.46 m (group 2, three PCBs), and 0.78 m (group 3, three PCBs) as the covariate of PHM respectively. The failure/censoring time of each BGA is given in Table A1 in the Appendix.

sec.title: 3.1.2 Results
sec.p: This section presents the implementation results of PHM based on the dataset in Table A1. To evaluate the capability of PHM for estimating the reliability characteristics of solder joints whose load conditions are not contained in the training dataset, three PHMs were established based on different training datasets. For convenience, we denote the PHMs as PHM(0.46, 0.78), PHM(0.34, 0.78), and PHM(0.34, 0.46), where PHM(a,b) is the PHM established based on the samples (in Table A1) whose drop height is either a or b. The parameters of the PHMs are summarized in Table 1.

caption.p: Parameters of the PHMs in the drop test

sec.p: In addition, for comparison purposes, another three Weibull distributions were fitted for the same task, which considered that all samples (with different drop height) were homogeneous and simply ignored the effect of drop height. In correspondence with the notation for PHMs, these three Weibull distributions were denoted as Weibull(0.46, 0.78), Weibull(0.34, 0.78), and Weibull(0.34, 0.46) respectively, where Weibull (a, b) denotes the Weibull distribution established based on the samples (in Table A1) whose drop heights were either a or b. The parameters for the Weibull distributions were also estimated by the MLE method, and are summarized in Table 2.

caption.p: Parameters of the Weibull distributions in the drop-impact test

sec.p: Next, the PHMs and the Weibull distributions were used to estimate the reliability characteristics (p.d.f. and MTTF) of the solder joints whose drop height are not contained in the training dataset, e.g. use PHM(0.46, 0.78) and Weibull(0.46, 0.78) for the solder joints with drop height = 0.34 m. For the purpose of illustration, the p.d.f. of PHM(0.46, 0.78), the p.d.f. of Weibull(0.46, 0.78), and the histogram of the lifetimes of samples with drop height = 0.34 m are shown in Fig. 3. Table 3 summarizes the estimation of MTTF. Table 4 summarizes the full likelihood for the samples (with a certain drop height = h in Table A1) under the PHM and Weibull modelsthat were established based on the rest of samples in Table A1 with dropheight≠h. The full likelihood could be calculated by substituting the parameters (e.g. γ^,η^,β^) and the samples’ failure/censoring times into the likelihood function (e.g. equation (3)). Typically, a larger likelihood means that the samples’ failures are more likely to occur jointly under the distribution model, and thus the distribution model provides a better estimate of the sample’s underlying lifetime distribution. The results in Tables 3 and 4 will be interpreted in more detail in section 3.3.

caption.p: p.d.f. of PHM(0.46, 0.78). p.d.f. of Weibull (0.46, 0.78), and histogram of the samples’ lifetimes with DH = 0.34 m

Estimation of MTTF (in the drop-impact test,) where ‘Empirical’ denotes the mean lifetime calculated from the samples’ lifetimes shown in Table A1 with the designated drop height, which ideally reflects the real MTTF of the solder joints with that drop height
Full likelihood for the samples’ failures/censorings (in Table A1) under the PHMs and Weibull models

sec.title: 3.2.1 Experiment setup and process
sec.p: In the vibration test, the same test board as used in the drop-impact test (illustrated in Fig. 1) was adopted. The experiment setup can be outlined in Fig. 4. In addition to the equipment and instruments in Fig. 4, a DC power supply and a power amplifier for the vibrator were also used in this test (but not shown in Fig. 4). As shown in Fig. 4 (middle photo of the lower row), the PCB was fixed on a base plate with eight standoffs, which was further connected with the vibrator through four larger standoffs. Ideally, the standoffs should be rigid, ensuring that the PCB, the base plate, and the vibrator move simultaneously.

caption.p: Experiment setup in the vibration test, where item 1: round test board, 2: accelerometer,3: charge amplifier, 4:LMS Test Lab, 5: interface of LMS Test Lab, 6: vibrator, 7: wires (for linking the daisy chain loop with the resistor), 8: resistor (R0), 9: recorder, 10: cable of the recorder (for measuring the voltage V0 across the resistor R0)

sec.p: The testing system consisted of items 1–6 in Fig. 4 and the power amplifier for the vibrator. In the process of vibration, the LMS Test Lab (item 4) controlled the vibrator (item 6) to vibrate under the designed condition, with the help of the feedback acceleration signals measured by the accelerometer (item 2) and amplified by the charge amplifier (item 3). The monitoring system consisted of items 7–10 in Fig. 4 plus the DC power supply, whose functionality can be explained by Fig. 5. The recorder displayed and recorded the voltage V0 across the external resistor R0, which was E[R0/(R0+Rx)]. Once any of the solder joints in the daisy chain loop break, Rx would be close to infinity (open circuit) and consequently V0 would be very close to zero.

caption.p: Schematic illustration of the monitoring system in the vibration test, where Rx is the equivalent resistance for the daisy chain loop linking the solder joints in series, E is the voltage (5 V) of the DC power supply

sec.p: A prior modal analysis and finite element analysis have shown that the first-order natural frequency of the PCB is close to 200 Hz. In the test, the vibrator was controlled to vibrate randomly in the frequency band between 190 Hz and 210 Hz, and the mean PSD in this frequency band was specified to be 160 m2/s3, 120 m2/s3, 80 m2/s3, and 60 m2/s3 respectively, with 10 per cent permissible interval up and down. Once the actual acceleration exceeded the permissible interval, the vibrator stopped with the warning of ‘overload’, and we adjusted the settings in LMS Test Lab and restated the vibration process with the same desired vibration condition. By the principle shown in Fig. 5 and the dynamic voltage V0 displayed by the recorder, the vibration process was controlled so that most of the BGAs failed in the test. Moreover, an offline and ex-post analysis of the recorded voltage V0 in the recorder helped to determine the failure/censoring time of each BGA. The vibration test was conducted for seven PCBs in all. The failure moment of each BGA under various vibration conditions are summarized in Table A2 in the Appendix.

sec.title: 3.2.2 Results
sec.p: This section presents the implementation results of PHM based on the dataset in Table A2. Herein, we have the same roadmap as that in section 3.1.2. The differences are that the PSD (instead of the drop height) was used as the covariate of PHM. Moreover, due to the existence of four PSD levels, four PHMs and four Weibull models were established. The estimated parameters of the PHMs and the Weibull models are summarized in Table 5 and 6 respectively. Moreover, (1) the estimation of MTTF and (2) the evaluation of the full likelihood for the samples in Table A2 under the PHM and Weibull models are summarized in Tables 7 and 8, as discussed in section 3.1.2. More detailed discussions on the results presented here are provided in section 3.3.

caption.p: Parameters of the PHMs in the vibration test, where PHM(a, b, c) denotes the PHM established based on the samples (in Table A2) whose PSD is one of a, b and c
Parameters of the Weibull distributions in the vibration test where Weibull (a, b, c) denotes the Weibull distribution established based on the samples (in Table A2) whose PSD is one of a, b and c
Estimation of MTTF (in the vibration test)
Full likelihood for the samples’ failures/censorings (in Table A2) under the PHMs and Weibull models.

sec.title: 3.3 Discussion
sec.p: This section discusses the results presented in sections 3.1.2 and 3.2.2 in more detail. From the results of MTTF estimation in Tables 3 and 7, it can be observed that Weibull(0.34, 0.78) in Table 3 and Weibull(160, 80, 60) in Table 7 slightly outperform PHM(0.34, 0.78) and PHM(160, 80, 60) respectively, by giving estimations closer to the empirical means: 34.31 (number of drops) and 1215.42 (s). However, for other cases, the estimations from the Weibull models are usually far from the desired empirical means. Incontrast, the PHMs consistently provide reasonable estimations in all cases, even when the Weibull models perform well (Weibull(0.34, 0.78) and Weibull(160, 80, 60)). Similarly, based on the results of full likelihood in Tables 4 and 8, the PHMs outperforms the Weibull models by providing better description of the joint occurrence of solder joints’ failures (failure/censoring times are summarized in Tables A1 and A2 for each load condition), except the case of PHM(160, 80, 60). It is noted that a better description of the variability (larger full likelihood value) does not necessarily guarantee a better estimation of the mean (i.e. MTTF), as is the case of PHM(0.34, 0.78) in Tables 3 and 4. It is also worth mentioning, based on the results for MTTF estimation and full likelihood, that Weibull models generally perform well for the median load levels (DH = 0.46 m, PSD = 120 m2/s3), which might be due to the averaging effect by mixing the samples with high load levels and low load levels. However, PHM is more effective for estimation of reliability characteristics due toits (1) consistency, and (2) superiority in most cases.

To use the PHM for other engineering applications, it is necessary to identify the covariates influencing system lifetime, collect the evolution history of each historical sample’s covariates and its failure time. Afterwards, the parameters in the PHM can be estimated following the procedures from equation (3) to equation (6). With the parameters estimated, the system’s reliability characteristics in untested conditions can be predicted by substituting the conditions (as covariates) into the established PHM.

sec.title: 4 Conclusions
sec.p: This paper studies the use of PHM for reliability analysis of solder joints through two case studies: a drop-impact test and a vibration test. The focus is on the use of a PHM to estimate the reliability characteristics of solder joints whose load conditions are not contained in the training dataset of the PHM. In comparison with the naive use of lifetime data by simply ignoring the effect of load conditions, the two case studies verify the effectiveness of PHM in providing consistent reasonable estimation of the reliability characteristics of solder joints. This advantage supports the use of PHM for predicting a system’s reliability characteristics in an untested condition in future practice.

caption.p: Failure/censoring times of BGA in the drop-impact test with three drop heights (in terms of drop numbers)

Failure/censoring times of BGA in the vibration test (in terms of seconds), where e denotes some unknown error (possibly problem of cable) that made the record abnormal such that the lifetime could not be determined
